search_information.query_displayed: Rationalization and Student/School Personhood in U.S. College Admissions: The Rise of Test-Optional Policies, 1987 to 2015 Furuta, Jared Sociology of Education

organic_results.title: Rationalization and student/school personhood in US college admissions: The rise of test-optional policies, 1987 to 2015
organic_results.snippet: This article examines the rise of ''test-optional''college admissions policies since the 1990s. I argue that the rationalization of college admissions policies after World War II contributed to the rise of ''meritocratic''stratification (in policy) and standardized tests, like the SAT, but it also led to the expansion and legitimation of the roles of student and school personhood in the admissions process. Schools more committed to enlarged conceptions of student personhood are more likely to adopt a test-optional policy, in order to recruit students who fit …

publication_info.summary: J Furuta - Sociology of Education, 2017 - journals.sagepub.com
